name: Hydromorphone
cautions: Use with extreme caution in respiratory compromise (e.g., acute asthma, COPD, OSA, severe pneumonia).
Risk of respiratory depression, especially in opioid-naïve patients, children, older adults, and those with comorbidities.
Caution in renal or hepatic impairment due to altered clearance and increased risk of accumulation.
Avoid or carefully monitor with other CNS depressants (benzodiazepines, alcohol, sedative-hypnotics).
May cause hypotension; use caution in hypovolemia or hemodynamic instability.
Risk of dependence, tolerance, and misuse; controlled substance.
Use caution in patients with increased intracranial pressure or head injury.
Adjust dose when converting from other opioids; hydromorphone is more potent than morphine mg-for-mg.

compatibility.iv: Generally compatible with normal saline (NS) and dextrose 5% in water (D5W). Y-site compatibility varies by co-infused drug; check institutional compatibility chart.
compatibility.oral: Swallow controlled-release tablets whole (do not crush); oral liquid may be mixed with a small amount of compatible fluid immediately before administration.
compatibility.other: Avoid mixing with solutions outside institutional standards without pharmacy verification.

indications: Moderate to severe acute pain (e.g., post-operative).
Severe chronic pain requiring continuous opioid therapy when alternative treatments are inadequate.
Breakthrough pain in patients receiving baseline opioid therapy.
sideEffects: Tolerance, physical dependence, risk of misuse
summary: Hydromorphone is a potent opioid analgesic used for moderate to severe pain. Compared to morphine, it is more potent on a milligram basis, so dose conversions must be done carefully. Main nursing concerns are respiratory depression, oversedation, hypotension, constipation, and safe titration based on pain scores and patient response.
